results.title: Alma de Groen
results.creator_credit: Otrun Zuber-Skerrit and Television Unit, University of Queensland
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Australian playwrights speak”.
Alma De Groen is one of Australia’s most innovative and challenging playwrights. This interview offers an enlightening introduction to her work. She speaks about her early plays and the emergence of her interest in the outsider figure, feminism, and developments in her latest work. She also discusses the inspiration she seeks from the work of visual artists for the form and style of her plays. Interviewed by Elizabeth Perkins.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Otrun Zuber-Skerrit and Television Unit, University of Queensland

results.title: Jack Hibberd
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Australian playwrights speak”.
An interview with Australian playwright Jack Hibberd by Paul McGillick. Jack Hibberd’s plays have been characterised by great comic invention and an exploration of theatrical forms.

results.title: Stephen Sewell
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian playwrights speak”.
Stephen Sewell’s plays have often aroused considerable controversy over their moral and political exploration. He discusses the influence of his Catholic, working-class background on his work.

results.title: Tomatoes for Troops
results.creator_credit: Bob Harper, Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture. Film Unit and Jack Keane
results.brief_description:
This film, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, is an example of propaganda for the war effort, encouraging farmers to grow tomatoes for the armed forces during the Second World War. The film includes footage of soldiers on the Kokoda Trail, and outlines the importance of vegetables for the armed forces in combat overseas.

The film takes the viewer through the stages of tomato production on a mass scale, showing the process of collecting, disinfecting and washing seeds; cultivating and fertilising the soil; planting the seedlings and maximising growth. The film then outlines common diseases and pests that threaten the healthy growth of tomato plants, such as spotted wilt, tomato moths and weevils, along with preventative measures to mitigate these risks.

Finally, the film shows the industrial-scale quality assessment and canning of tomatoes in a factory. The final product, shown in the hands of an active soldier, is a can of SPC peeled tomatoes.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bob Harper, Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture. Film Unit and Jack Keane

results.title: Stop fruitfly (picture only)
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Colin Webb
results.brief_description: Picture-only print in fair/good condition. Details the way in which fruitflys can infiltrate between state borders and ruin fruit in victoria. Nicely shot with good footage of white-jacketed inspectors, people dissembarking from an Ansett plane and fruitfly-infested oranges. Also contains a shot of the ‘Frankston Marine Centre’ truck. Nicely illustrated ‘The End’.

results.title: Potash deficiency Hamilton district
results.brief_description: No sound. Long-duration shots of clovers, fields and farmers walking through fields. Ends with footage of a manually-operated farming device that either plants seeds or removes plants.

results.title: Portland beef carcase competition 1960
results.brief_description: Promotional film highlighting the quality of Victorian beef. Shots of people looking at meat, etc throughout. Includes disturbing footage of beef carcases being hung. Great ‘The End’ title. See Also: 1955 Pig Carcase Competition at Dandenong and 1957 Pig Carcase Competition at Dandenong.

results.title: La Trobe Cottage [B&W]
results.creator_credit: National Trust, John Kingsford-Smith, Ampol Petroleum Ltd and Kingcroft Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Heritage”.
A look at La Trobe Cottage, Victoria’s first Government House. Brought out from England, it was assembled on a foundation of hand-make bricks.
results.creator_credit_for_label: National Trust, John Kingsford-Smith, Ampol Petroleum Ltd and Kingcroft Productions

results.title: Beechworth [B&W]
results.creator_credit: National Trust, John Kingsford-Smith and Ampol Petroleum Ltd
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Heritage”.
Historic buildings of the former gold mining town of Beechworth, Vic., including the gold office, prison, powder magazine, churches and the Court House where Ned Kelly was tried three times.
results.creator_credit_for_label: National Trust, John Kingsford-Smith and Ampol Petroleum Ltd
